number.text: So in order to get a nice 3D image in perspective, we need to apply different matrices to different

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: coordinates. Let's take a look at these types of coordinates.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: First, we have the local coordinates.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: These are the coordinates whose origin is the same as an object's origin.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: These are usually located at the centre of an object, but that's not always the case.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: Then we have the world coordinates whose origin is at the centre of the world.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: These coordinates usually contain the location of other objects.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: Next, we have the view coordinates which have the same origin as a camera or viewpoint.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: Notice that these do not yet account for perspective.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: Perspective is added in the next set of coordinates, which are the clip coordinates.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: These are essentially the same as the view coordinates, except the clip,

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: aka delete, and the vertices outside the normalized range, and can also account for perspective.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: And the final coordinates are the screen coordinates where everything is flattened out such that it

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: can be viewed on your screen.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: Now, in order to move from a coordinate system to the next, we make use of matrices.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: There are three main matrices we make use of.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: The model matrix, which takes local coordinates to world coordinates.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: The view matrix, which takes world coordinates to view coordinates, and the projection matrix,

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: which takes view coordinates to clip coordinates.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: The final transformation from clip coordinates to space coordinates is done automatically.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: All these matrices we are applying are 4D, but we won't have to actually write them

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: more cells since GLM can take care of that.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: So, let's create the model matrix.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: We serve by creating a variable called model of type mat4,

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: and equaling it to the identity matrix, which is simply mat4 1.0.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: This is called initialization, and it must be done, since otherwise,

number.title: Going 3D.mp4

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: empty matrix. Initialize the other two matrices as well.

number.text: But right now, our camera is also in the center, so we want to move back and also be top.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: But it's not really us doing this, but the world itself.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: We are essentially moving the whole world around us instead of us moving around the whole world.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: In any case, to do this, we are going to use the function translate,

number.text: plugging in our view matrix, and the vector, which will indicate in which direction and how much

number.text: in radians, the aspect ratio of our screen, and the closest and furthest point we can see.

number.title: Going 3D.mp4
number.text: In other words, if something is closer than 0.1 units to us, then it will be clipped,

number.text: and if it's further away than 100.0 units, it will again get clipped.

number.text: Notice that I've used the function radians to transform my degrees into radians.

number.text: so we can easily modify them from now on.

number.text: Now all that's left to do is to import these matrices into the vertex shader.
